subject: RE: [junit] Testing Private Methods

messageBody:
I think your first and second questions are related.

I realize this has all been hashed over many times, but
here's my take.

If you are testing private methods, it is possibly
a code smell that your class is too large. The private
functionality being tested perhaps belongs in another
class. The privates become publics in the new class,
eliminating the issue of having to test privates.

Another possible downside of testing privates is that
it can be a hindrance to refactoring. The nice thing
about not testing private methods is that you are free
to change the implementation of your class with
impunity. When client test code uses privates, it makes
refactoring far more difficult.

That said, I do find myself testing privates sometimes.
In the course of incremental development, my goal is to
get to a green bar within a very brief amount of time.
As such, I've found sometimes the best way to accomplish
this with a large piece of functionality is to decompose
it into pieces of the overall algorithm. These become
privates (technically package or protected in Java), each
of which gets tested individually.

Anyway, regarding private methods in servlets: view
servlets as the user interface code. You really can't
test privates (what I call "side effects") of servlets
easily. All you can effectively do is test expected
output (URLs & HTML) against input (key-value pairs)
via HTTPUnit or some other similar tool.

If you find yourself needing to test privates, then, it
suggests that the servlet code is doing too much. My
servlets are virtually empty: the service methods simply
delegate things off to some other model object. The model
(which represents application concerns at this level) has
already been built test-first.

-Jeff

>
> Yes. Don't test protected and package-protected methods.
>
> A quote from the XP discussion group.
> (http://208.48.218.9/group/extremeprogramming/message/13213)
>
> "I actually do think that it is cut and dried. Public members have a
> behavior that is expected of them by their clients. Tests can
> be used to
> define that behavior and demonstrate that a particular method
> exhibits it.
> Private methods are, by definition, implementation details.
> Their behavior
> can vary freely so long as the public methods don't break.
> Put another way:
> if every public method has been proven to behave correctly
> then the class
> has been proven to be bug free. Therefore, there is never a
> need to test
> the private members of a class."
>
> So can you avoid testing them? If so, then don't; if not,
> then you can't
> have it both ways: either the tests are in the class (to test private
> methods),
> in the package (to test protected/package methods) or you
> can't test those
> methods. There's no magic here...
>
> Good luck,
>

> Can anyone point me to a good source of information on using JUNIT for
> testing private methods and package-protected methods. It
> seems like its
> not going to be possible to do it while separating the
> TestCase classes and
> the business object classes.
>
> One of the reasons I see a difficulty is that we are using
> VisualAge for
> Java and it would make it a deployment nightmare to include
> the code in the
> same packages or, worse yet, the same classes. I know that there are
> options I could use outside of VA such as ANT to only build certain
> classes,
> but I doubt I could get the client to buy into that and I
> still don't think
> that solves the private method issue.
>
> Am I just missing something easy or what?
>
> Thanks,
